clusters.title: U.S. launches Christmas Day strikes on ISIS targets in Nigeria, Trump says
clusters.neutral_headline: US launches strikes against Islamic State in Nigeria

items.title: U.S. launches Christmas Day strikes on ISIS targets in Nigeria, Trump says
items.standfirst: The strikes come after President Trump spent weeks accusing the West African country's government of failing to rein in the persecution of Christians.
items.content: The strikes come after President Trump spent weeks accusing the West African country's government of failing to rein in the persecution of Christians.

items.title: Nigeria provided US with intelligence for strikes on Islamist militants, says foreign minister – US politics live
items.standfirst: Yusuf Tuggar says strikes against group accused by Donald Trump of attacking Christian communities will be an ‘ongoing process’Nigeria provided the US with intelligence on jihadists before the strikes that took place in the country on Christmas Day, its foreign ministry said on Friday.On Thursday, the US president, Donald Trump, said the US military had carried out strikes against Islamic State militants in north-west Nigeria, after spending weeks decrying the group for targeting Christians. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: Trump announces strikes in Nigeria against Islamic State group targets
items.standfirst: The US carried out a strike against Islamic State group militants in northwest Nigeria at the request of Nigeria's government, US President Donald Trump and the US military said on Thursday, claiming the group had been targeting Christians in the region. FRANCE 24 correspondent Chinwe Ossundu reports the latest from Nigeria.
items.content: The US carried out a strike against Islamic State group militants in northwest Nigeria at the request of Nigeria's government, US President Donald Trump and the US military said on Thursday, claiming the group had been targeting Christians in the region. FRANCE 24 correspondent Chinwe Ossundu reports the latest from Nigeria.

items.standfirst: President Donald Trump has previously accused the Nigerian government of failing to protect Christians from jihadist groups.
items.content: President Donald Trump has previously accused the Nigerian government of failing to protect Christians from jihadist groups.

items.title: US launches air strikes against Islamic State militants in Nigeria
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump said Thursday that the US had launched "precision hits on terrorist targets in Nigeria by air strikes". The claim came in a Christmas night social media post that offered few details, though US Africa Command later confirmed the strikes were conducted at the request of Nigerian authorities that said it killed multiple Islamic State militants. Washington Bureau Chief of The Guardian, David Smith, explains.
items.content: President Donald Trump said Thursday that the US had launched "precision hits on terrorist targets in Nigeria by air strikes". The claim came in a Christmas night social media post that offered few details, though US Africa Command later confirmed the strikes were conducted at the request of Nigerian authorities that said it killed multiple Islamic State militants. Washington Bureau Chief of The Guardian, David Smith, explains.

The claim came in a Christmas night social media post that offered few details, though US Africa Command later confirmed the strikes were conducted at the request of Nigerian authorities who said multiple Islamic State group militants were killed.

items.title: U.S. says it targets ISIS in Nigeria after Trump warns of attacks on Christians
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump on Thursday said he ordered “numerous” strikes on Islamic State terrorists in Nigeria he accused of killing Christians."The United States launched a powerful and deadly strike against ISIS Terrorist Scum in Northwest Nigeria, who have been targeting and viciously killing, primarily, innocent Christians, at levels not seen for many years, and even Centuries!," Trump said in a post on Truth Social

clusters.title: Zelensky holds talks with US negotiators, as fighting continues on the Ukrainian ground
clusters.neutral_headline: Zelensky hails 'new ideas' on peace after talks with US envoys

items.title: Zelensky holds talks with US negotiators, as fighting continues on the Ukrainian ground
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has signaled possible progress toward a peace agreement with Russia after what he described as a “really good conversation” with the US special envoy on Christmas Day, adding that he plans to meet Donald Trump soon to advance efforts to end the nearly four-year war. Recent talks between US and Ukrainian delegations have reportedly resulted in a 20-point proposal that has been sent to Moscow for feedback, even as fighting continues on the ground, with Russia launching more than 100 missiles into Ukraine overnight, as Charlotte Lam reports.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has signaled possible progress toward a peace agreement with Russia after what he described as a “really good conversation” with the US special envoy on Christmas Day, adding that he plans to meet Donald Trump soon to advance efforts to end the nearly four-year war. Recent talks between US and Ukrainian delegations have reportedly resulted in a 20-point proposal that has been sent to Moscow for feedback, even as fighting continues on the ground, with Russia launching more than 100 missiles into Ukraine overnight, as Charlotte Lam reports.

clusters.title: Former Malaysian PM Najib found guilty of money laundering in 1MDB corruption case
clusters.neutral_headline: Malaysia’s ex-PM Najib found guilty of money laundering, abuse of power

items.title: Former Malaysian PM Najib found guilty of money laundering in 1MDB corruption case
items.standfirst: Malaysia's High Court on Friday found former Malaysian prime minister Najib Razak guilty of all 21 counts of money laundering related to the sprawling corruption scandal involving Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB). This conviction is likely to add years to the prison sentence he is already serving.
items.content: Malaysia's High Court on Friday found former Malaysian prime minister Najib Razak guilty of all 21 counts of money laundering related to the sprawling corruption scandal involving Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB). This conviction is likely to add years to the prison sentence he is already serving.

items.title: Former Malaysian PM Najib Razak found guilty of abuse of power in latest 1MDB trial
items.standfirst: Najib has been in prison since August 2022, when Malaysia’s top court upheld a corruption conviction. He denies wrongdoingJailed former Malaysian prime minister Najib Razak has been found guilty of abuse of power, in the biggest trial yet in the multibillion-dollar fraud scandal related to state fund 1MDB.Najib had been charged with four counts of corruption and 21 counts of money laundering for receiving illegal transfers of about 2.2bn ringgit ($544.15m) from 1MDB. He has consistently denied wrongdoing. Continue reading...
items.content: Najib has been in prison since August 2022, when Malaysia’s top court upheld a corruption conviction. He denies wrongdoingJailed former Malaysian prime minister Najib Razak has been found guilty of abuse of power, in the biggest trial yet in the multibillion-dollar fraud scandal related to state fund 1MDB.Najib had been charged with four counts of corruption and 21 counts of money laundering for receiving illegal transfers of about 2.2bn ringgit ($544.15m) from 1MDB. He has consistently denied wrongdoing. Continue reading...

items.content: Malaysian High Court finds former PM Najib guilty in trial related to the 1MDB sovereign wealth fund scandal.

clusters.title: Bangladesh's PM front-runner Tarique Rahman returns after 17 years
clusters.neutral_headline: Front-runner to be Bangladesh PM returns after 17 years in exile

items.title: Bangladesh's PM front-runner Tarique Rahman returns after 17 years
items.standfirst: Hundreds of thousands of BNP supporters gathered in Dhaka to welcome the party's acting chief Tarique Rahman, who returned to Bangladesh after 17 years in exile. In his first remarks after returning, Rahman called for communal harmony and promised to unveil a plan for Bangladesh. Charlotte Lam reports.
items.content: Hundreds of thousands of BNP supporters gathered in Dhaka to welcome the party's acting chief Tarique Rahman, who returned to Bangladesh after 17 years in exile. In his first remarks after returning, Rahman called for communal harmony and promised to unveil a plan for Bangladesh. Charlotte Lam reports.

clusters.title: Flash floods hit Southern California, State of emergency declared
clusters.neutral_headline: Heavy rain storms in California leave three dead

items.title: Flash floods hit Southern California, State of emergency declared
items.standfirst: Deadly storms raged through Christmas in Southern California, where they are expected to persist Friday. Many have had to evacuate their homes as firefighters rescue residents trapped from the severe conditions, which have blocked roads and cut power across the state. Gabrielle Nadler has the story.
items.content: Deadly storms raged through Christmas in Southern California, where they are expected to persist Friday. Many have had to evacuate their homes as firefighters rescue residents trapped from the severe conditions, which have blocked roads and cut power across the state. Gabrielle Nadler has the story.

items.title: California: Wettest Christmas in years as more heavy rains expected
items.standfirst: Heavy rains in California have triggered floods and mudslides that killed three people, according to local officials, forcing evacuations and the closure of major roads after up to 27 centimeters of rain fell in parts of Los Angeles County. The storms also caused widespread power outages, leaving around 100,000 people across the state without electricity on Christmas, with more rain expected through Friday. In response, Governor Gavin Newsom declared a state of emergency in six California counties, as reported by France 24’s Los Angeles correspondent, Wassim Cornet.
items.content: Heavy rains in California have triggered floods and mudslides that killed three people, according to local officials, forcing evacuations and the closure of major roads after up to 27 centimeters of rain fell in parts of Los Angeles County. The storms also caused widespread power outages, leaving around 100,000 people across the state without electricity on Christmas, with more rain expected through Friday. In response, Governor Gavin Newsom declared a state of emergency in six California counties, as reported by France 24’s Los Angeles correspondent, Wassim Cornet.

items.title: Heavy rain storms in California leave three dead
items.standfirst: A state of emergency is declared in Los Angeles and other southern counties after flash floods and mudslides.
items.content: A state of emergency is declared in Los Angeles and other southern counties after flash floods and mudslides.

clusters.title: More than a million new Epstein documents found, review underway
clusters.neutral_headline: Officials discover a million more documents potentially related to Epstein case

items.title: More than a million new Epstein documents found, review underway
items.standfirst: The US Department of Justice announced on Wednesday that it had discovered more than a million additional documents potentially linked to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, which are now under review for possible release, prompting renewed criticism from several Democratic lawmakers and Epstein’s victims, who demanded greater transparency and condemned the department’s controversial handling of the case, as reported by Laurent Berstecher.
items.content: The US Department of Justice announced on Wednesday that it had discovered more than a million additional documents potentially linked to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, which are now under review for possible release, prompting renewed criticism from several Democratic lawmakers and Epstein’s victims, who demanded greater transparency and condemned the department’s controversial handling of the case, as reported by Laurent Berstecher.

items.title: Officials discover a million more documents potentially related to Epstein case
items.standfirst: The US Department of Justice says reviewing the material could delay the full release of Epstein documents by a "few more weeks".
items.content: The US Department of Justice says reviewing the material could delay the full release of Epstein documents by a "few more weeks".

items.title: Unpublished ‘Tupperware erotica’ novel prompts fierce contest for TV rights
items.standfirst: Interest in Wet Ink by Abigail Avis is part of a trend for works by female authors among streamers and production companies A much-hyped novel about a housewife who uses Tupperware parties to secretly smuggle erotic stories to her friends and neighbours is causing a stir in the television world, igniting a fierce bidding contest over the right to adapt it for the small screen.Wet Ink, a novel by the 33-year-old London-based author Abigail Avis, is not scheduled to be published until the spring 2027, but industry insiders said a fierce auction between six major production companies had already taken place for the TV rights. Continue reading...

items.title: ‘All brakes are off’: Russia’s attempt to rein in illicit market for leaked data backfires
items.standfirst: Russian state has tolerated parallel probiv market for its convenience but now Ukrainian spies are exploiting it Russia is scrambling to rein in the country’s sprawling illicit market for leaked personal data, a shadowy ecosystem long exploited by investigative journalists, police and criminal…
items.content: Russian state has tolerated parallel probiv market for its convenience but now Ukrainian spies are exploiting it Russia is scrambling to rein in the country’s sprawling illicit market for leaked personal data, a shadowy ecosystem long exploited by investigative journalists, police and criminal…

items.title: ‘All brakes are off’: Russia’s attempt to rein in illicit market for leaked data backfires
items.standfirst: Russian state has tolerated parallel probiv market for its convenience but now Ukrainian spies are exploiting itRussia is scrambling to rein in the country’s sprawling illicit market for leaked personal data, a shadowy ecosystem long exploited by investigative journalists, police and criminal groups.For more than a decade, Russia’s so-called probiv market – a term derived from the verb “to pierce” or “to punch into a search bar” – has operated as a parallel information economy built on a network of corrupt officials, traffic police, bank employees and low-level security staff willing to sell access to restricted government or corporate databases. Continue reading...
items.content: Russian state has tolerated parallel probiv market for its convenience but now Ukrainian spies are exploiting itRussia is scrambling to rein in the country’s sprawling illicit market for leaked personal data, a shadowy ecosystem long exploited by investigative journalists, police and criminal groups.For more than a decade, Russia’s so-called probiv market – a term derived from the verb “to pierce” or “to punch into a search bar” – has operated as a parallel information economy built on a network of corrupt officials, traffic police, bank employees and low-level security staff willing to sell access to restricted government or corporate databases. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: Sector reinvests in high-end experiences, from front-row beds to premier pods and business class-style seats with built-in wine coolers From champagne coolers to front row VIP beds, cinema owners are investing heavily in premium experiences as the industry gets its box office mojo back. items.title: VIP viewing: cinemas bet on luxury bars and beds to usher in a new film era
items.standfirst: Sector reinvests in high-end experiences, from front-row beds to premier pods and business class-style seats with built-in wine coolersFrom champagne coolers to front row VIP beds, cinema owners are investing heavily in premium experiences as the industry gets its box office mojo back.As the third instalment in James Cameron’s blockbuster Avatar series pulls in the Christmas holiday crowds, the UK box office is expected to surpass £1bn in 2025 for the first time since before the global Covid pandemic. items.title: Brazil ex-President Jair Bolsonaro's surgery for hernia 'successful'
items.standfirst: The former leader is serving a 27-year sentence for plotting a coup after losing the 2022 presidential election.
items.content: The former leader is serving a 27-year sentence for plotting a coup after losing the 2022 presidential election.

items.title: Brazil’s jailed ex-president Bolsonaro undergoes 'successful' hernia surgery
items.standfirst: Former Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro, who was serving a 27-year prison sentence for an attempted coup, underwent successful hernia surgery in Brasília after being temporarily released from jail. Doctors said he was expected to remain hospitalised for several days.
items.content: Former Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro, who was serving a 27-year prison sentence for an attempted coup, underwent successful hernia surgery in Brasília after being temporarily released from jail. Doctors said he was expected to remain hospitalised for several days.

clusters.title: Algerian law declares France's colonisation a crime
clusters.neutral_headline: Algerian law declares France's colonisation a crime

items.title: Algerian law declares France's colonisation a crime
items.standfirst: Lawmakers unanimously approve a law, which demands an apology and reparations from the former colonial power.
items.content: Lawmakers unanimously approve a law, which demands an apology and reparations from the former colonial power.

items.title: Algeria passes law declaring French colonisation a crime
items.standfirst: France’s rule over Algeria from 1830 to 1962 is marked by mass killings and large-scale deportationAlgeria’s parliament has unanimously approved a law declaring France’s colonisation of the country a crime and demanded an apology and reparations.Lawmakers, standing in the chamber wearing scarves in the colours of the national flag, chanted “long live Algeria” on Wednesday as they applauded the passage of the bill, which states that France holds “legal responsibility for its colonial past in Algeria and the tragedies it caused”. Continue reading...
items.content: France’s rule over Algeria from 1830 to 1962 is marked by mass killings and large-scale deportationAlgeria’s parliament has unanimously approved a law declaring France’s colonisation of the country a crime and demanded an apology and reparations.Lawmakers, standing in the chamber wearing scarves in the colours of the national flag, chanted “long live Algeria” on Wednesday as they applauded the passage of the bill, which states that France holds “legal responsibility for its colonial past in Algeria and the tragedies it caused”. Continue reading...
